brief_description of the content in the: The source URL describes a rule that identifies JUnit 3 style test methods that are located inside a class that does not extend the JUnit 3 TestCase class but contains JUnit 4 or JUnit 5 @Test annotated methods. These test methods cannot be run.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'old_style_junit_test_method_in_junit4_class' checks all classes in the project. If a class does not have the JUnit 4 or JUnit 5 @Test annotation, it checks all methods in the class. If a method starts with 'test' and does not have the @Test annotation, it asserts that the superclass of the class is 'junit.framework.TestCase'. If the superclass is not 'junit.framework.TestCase', it generates a message indicating that the JUnit 3 style test method in the JUnit 4 class cannot be run.
new_built-in_functions_explanation if an: The built-in functions used in this rule are: getClasses, hasAnnotation, getMethods, startsWith, getName, assert, getSuperclass, getFQN, and msg. No new functions were introduced.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/junit-5-migration
Summary: This page provides a guide on migrating from JUnit 4 to JUnit 5. It mentions that JUnit 3 style test methods that start with 'test' and are located in a class that does not extend the JUnit 3 TestCase class but contains JUnit 4 or JUnit 5 @Test annotated methods cannot be run.

2. URL: https://www.javaworld.com/article/2074569/make-the-most-of-junit-4-with-new-annotations-and-old-assertions.html
Summary: This page discusses the new annotations in JUnit 4 and how they differ from JUnit 3. It also mentions that JUnit 3 style test methods in a JUnit 4 class cannot be run unless the class extends 'junit.framework.TestCase'.
